newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian T-bills open mixed in quiet activity.
newsitem.headline: Canadian T-bills open mixed in quiet activity.

text.p: Canadian T-bills opened mixed in quiet trade on Wednesday, with the market seen trading in a narrow range for the rest of the session.

"Tomorrow should be a busy day so I think the market's going to take a breather to try to get things in order and figure out what they're going to do for tomorrow. And with no main numbers today we're probably just going to drift," said one T-bill trader with a bank-owned brokerage.
Canada's three-month when-issued T-bill softened to yield 3.34 percent from 3.33 percent from the close of trading on Tuesday.
Tomorrow will see C$7.9 billion of T-bills mature, an unusually high number because of a C$3.0 billion 35-day cash management T-bill auctioned on July 2.
The trader said much of that money could remain in the very short end of the money market yield curve, keeping short term T-bill prices well-bid.

Analysts said the Canadian money market is also coming to terms by the Canadian government's announcement yesterday that it will move to T-bill auctions every other week rather than every week. The move is aimed at increasing liquidity in the money market.

"I think it's going to help permit more liquidity in the cash and WI (when-issued) markets, but we're still trying to figure out what that's going to do to the current bill inventories," the T-bill trader said.
In other prices, the six-month cash T-bill softened to yield 3.73 percent from 3.71 percent on Tuesday. The one-year when-issued T-bill softened to yield 4.26 percent from 4.25 percent.
The call loan or overnight lending rate traded at 3.25 percent, the center of the Bank of Canada's 3.0-3.5 percent target range.
